abstract.text: An object that manages a custom view—known as an accessory view—in the title bar–toolbar area of a window.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Because a title bar accessory view controller is contained in a visual effect view (that is,

), it automatically handles the blur behind the accessory view and the size and location changes for the content of the view when a window goes in and out of full screen mode. If you’re currently using
object, give it your custom view, set the
property to ensure that it displays correctly in relation to the title bar, and add the view controller to your window. For more information about
methods you can use to add and remove a title bar accessory view controller, see Managing Title Bars.
observes the view’s frame for changes. Depending on the value of
, you can change either the height or the width of the view. Specifically, you can change the view’s height when
, and you can change the view’s width when the
. The remaining size direction is automatically set to the maximum size as required for the window.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
An object that manages the timing and progress of animations in the user interface.
A set of optional methods implemented by delegates of
objects.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
An object that manages a custom view—known as an accessory view—in the title bar–toolbar area of a window.
The visual minimum height of an accessory view that displays below the title bar when the window is in full screen mode.
The location of the accessory view, in relation to the window’s title bar.
Called when the title bar accessory view controller’s view is fully transitioned onto the screen.
Called after the title bar accessory view controller’s view is removed from the window’s view hierarchy.
Called after the title bar accessory view controller’s view has been loaded into memory is about to be added to the view hierarchy in the window.
An object that manages the space above your app’s custom content and either below or integrated with the window’s title bar.
The toolbar’s full screen accessory view.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
Instantiates a view from a nib file and sets the value of the
property.
The view controller’s primary view.
A view that adds translucency and vibrancy effects to the views in your interface.
A window that an app displays on the screen.
A controller that manages a window, usually a window stored in a nib file.
The bottom of the object’s alignment rectangle.
The left side of the object’s alignment rectangle.
The right side of the object’s alignment rectangle.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
